185985915.review:
I was initially drawn to this game due to its VERY well-aging visuals and the parkour gameplay, but wow.. the gameplay itself has not aged well *at all*. Yes, it looks nice, and there are early levels and many segments that are VERY good and flow well, but when you keep playing it just gets worse and worse. The running can be great, but the flow often gets destroyed, with you often getting stopped by incredibly awkward puzzles or combat that feels totally wrong. In modern games, a horrendous combat system would indicate that you're supposed to avoid combat and use it as only a last resort... but this game does NOT function like that. The main character, Faith, has very simple controls that usually flow super well, but every so often the game will throw you into a room or sequence that feels like you're totally missing one of her movement options (you won't be, it'll just be an incredibly obtuse solution). While the game is good at pointing you in the right direction early on, it very quickly devolves into stopping and looking around constantly and getting punished for choosing the wrong arbitrary direction. The game has a "hint" system to point you in the right direction which is nice, but should not be as mandatory as it is. There's a lot of design decisions like constant checkpoints, no penalty for death, instant respawns, and the hint system, which seem to try and be a bandaid solution to the issues with the game, but the flow was so bafflingly bad because of how much you'll hit roadblocks, that I lost a lot of enjoyment quickly from it.

While this game set the groundwork for many speed/parkour games of the future, it has so, so many moments and design decisions that made me question what I'm even doing. The game has great moments but has far too many segments that don't have the foresight of modern game design and this makes half the game feel like a slog as a result.

185794338.review:
I love this game, played it first when it came out in 2008 for many hours. 
Faith's perseverance throughout the story has always inspired me. She manifests her unrelenting sense of freedom in a city, that has made such ideas taboo, through her parkour skills. While the city of Glass represents a magnifying glass on it its citizens through extensive 'big brother' like policies and technology and forces them to compliance, Faith chooses utter defiance with her duty as a "runner". She acts as a conduit for parties who require the kind of aid the authoritarian city of Glass would deem as a threat to its power. The constant focus on the color red is a symbolic as it is aesthetic. This is due to  red being associated with passion and Faith following it throughout the gameplay is akin to following her passion. I think this is an experience that is well worth the time and money, and i also think it should make us question things we take for granted in our current system.

185754106.review: I understand this is a beloved franchise for many players, and it was very innovative for it's time, but I did not enjoy this game. Firstly, the game kept crashing my computer just before starting the first mission, and it wasn't fixed until I disabled Phys X settings. The "combat" is pretty awful and inconsistent. Even with Runner Vision and Faith's camera pointing me in the direction of my objective, the way forward was often difficult to figure out, and even then half the time the platforming just did not work the first time. I found the story so dull and uninteresting, and by the time I got to the final chapter, I didn't have the motivation to play anymore and uninstalled the game. There's elements of a good game here, but not enough to make it fun for me, and the jankey combat and occasionally broken mechanics do nothing but age this game. Nowadays there are plenty of other parkour games you can be playing that likely do everything better than this game (except maybe the roll animation, that was the game's highlight for me).

185749973.review:
[h1] Невеличкий відгук на Мірорс Едж [/h1]

Одна з улюблених ігор мого дитинства, до якої я стабільно повертаюся кожні 2-3 роки. Сьогодні вона знову попалася мені на очі і забезпечила ще один хороший, сповнений приємної ностальгії вечір.

Mirror's Edge представляє гравцю яскраве, ідеально чисте (майже) місто майбутнього, кожен метр якого контролюється жорстким, тоталітарним урядом. Гра розповідає історію Фейт - молодої дівчини, яка є частиною підпільного угрупування "бігунів" і одного разу стикається з сімейними проблемами, які їй необхідно подолати. Бігуни в свою чергу, це щось на кшталт місцевих кур'єрів, що бігають по дахам хмарочосів, використовуючи для пересування елементи паркуру і фізично передають різного роду інформацію замовникам, уникаючи загальних цифрових каналів. Не буду багато розповідати про сюжет, він досить легенький і явно не є найсильнішою стороною гри, дізнаєтеся самі :>

Гра повністю лінійна і всі рівні проходяться по заданому маршруту, проте іноді в деяких місцях можна заплутатися, тому гравцю допомагає "зір бігуна" - цікава механіка, що підсвічує ключові об'єкти червоним кольором. Фейт навчена багатьом паркурним елементам і активно застосовує їх кожної хвилини, а сам паркур тут цілком зав'язаний на її швидкості. Часто на локаціях нам будуть заважати поліція, спецназ, снайпера та навіть вертольоти з кулеметами за борту, але не бійтеся, бо вороги тут стріляють з заплющеними очима, тримаючи приклад біля лоба, тому що я не можу знайти інше логічне пояснення тому, що по мені не попадали троє SWAT'овців з дробовиками з п'яти метрів, поки я залазив по стіні вгору. Окрім паркуру, наша азіаточка ще й може дати ворогам тирки і роззброїти їх за дві секунди, але стрільба тут трошкі шакальна, тому особисто я віддаю перевагу швиденько драпати від мєнтів, все одно ж не попадуть. Окрім основного сюжету тут ще є випробування, представлені у вигляді забігів на певних локаціях з таймером. Я не дуже цікавився цим режимом, колись давненько пробував грати в нього, тому на цей рахунок більше сказати нічого. Єдиний мінус гри - це її тривалість: проходиться за 4-5 годин, а сьогодні я пробіг її всього лише за 3. Але ж завжди можна перепройти :)

Що стосується графіки, то завдяки своєму мінімалізму, яскравим скляним будівлям та контрастній кольоровій гаммі гра навіть зараз виглядає досить гарно та естетично, можу тільки уявити якою вона була в 2009. Робота зі світлом на деяких локаціях ідеальна без зайвих слів, хоча трапляються вже занадто яскраві місця. Невеличка ремарка: відразу вимикайте PhysX при першому запуску гри, якщо ви не мазохіст, що полюбляє смакувати екшн ігри в 10 фпс.

Найбільше я люблю Mirror's Edge за її атмосферу, бо завдяки своєму дизайну і саундтрекам вона забезпечує повне занурення в ігровий процес, а кожне падіння Фейт з даху будинку на землю я переживаю разом з нею. Під час взаємодії з оточенням ми завжди бачимо руки та [u] ноги [/u] головної героїні. Інші розробники рідко додають цей елемент в свої ігри від першої особи, хоча насправді це додає чимало реалізму. В цій грі повністю відсутній інтерфейс, не враховуючи крапки по центру екрана, але він тут і не потрібен, тому що гравця постійно скеровує зір бігуна.

Розробники разом з Solar Fields створили один з найкращих ігрових саундтреків, що мені коли-небудь доводилося чути.  Більшою мірою саме завдяки саунд-дизайну Mirror's Edge і є такою атмосферною, бо музика тут задає темп та може як потримати гравця в напрузі, так і допомогти розслабитися. Ембієнт на локаціях також неперевершений, іноді хочеться просто зупинитися і послухати його.

Загалом, для мене Mirror's Edge є грою на тверду 10/10 і вже багато років займає особливе місце в серці, рекомендую спробувати її кожному, якщо ви й досі цього не зробили.

185742087.review:
[b] Parkour, but Make It Art [/b]

You play as Faith Connors, a runner navigating a dystopian city where information is tightly controlled, and parkour is her tool of rebellion. The story is a decent excuse to keep running, involving corporate conspiracies and family drama.

The parkour mechanics feel intuitive yet demand precision. When you’re chaining movements seamlessly, it’s poetry in motion. When you’re not, it’s an awkward interpretive dance with the respawn screen. Combat feels deliberately clunky, a reminder that Faith is a runner, not a fighter. Disarming enemies is satisfying, though, but half the time it's better to just run away and leave them confused.

The game’s visual style is striking—a minimalistic palette dominated by stark whites and splashes of vibrant reds. These reds aren’t just decoration; they’re guideposts, a silent language telling you where to run, where to leap, and where to trust that gravity won’t betray you. Light is used masterfully, painting the sterile urban environment with sharp shadows and gleaming reflections. The minimalism isn’t just aesthetic; it’s functional, allowing the player to focus on the rhythm of running, leaping, and navigating.

"Mirror’s Edge" is a game that rewards perfection and punishes hesitation. It’s an unforgettable experience—a game that values innovation over convention, style over excess.

Mirror's Edge parkurun çoğunlukla ön planda olduğu biraz aksiyon ve nereye gideceğini bulman gerektiğinden birazcık da bulmaca içeren bir yapım. Oyunun ana mekaniği olan parkur oldukça iyi kotarılmış. O hayallerinde kurduğun şuraya koşayım buraya koşayım hissiyatı oldukça güzel. Platform oyunları gibi sadece şuraya atla buraya atla gibi değil minik minik mekaniklerle güzel bir oynanış yapılmış. Oyun oldukça iyi sinematik bir oynanışa sahip. Özellikle sen koşarken arkandan Hollywood filmleri gibi seni vuramayan ama sağına soluna sıkıp sinematik bir sahne yaratan durumlar dolu. Güzel kısacası.  Genel yapı seni hikayeye göre bir chapter'a atıyor açık dünya gibi gözüksede oldukça koridor şeklinde bir yapıda parkurlar yapıp en sona gelmeye çalışıyorsun. Bunlar olurken aynı zamanda hikaye de akıyor. Hikayesi bence oldukça güzel. Aşırı mükemmel , çığır açıcı bir hikaye değil ama güzel. Biz o zamanki baştaki büyük adamlara göre anarşist isyancı bir ekibin parçasıyız. Biz onları onlar bizi tokatlamaya çalışıyor. Bu baştaki büyük adamlar onların düşüncelerine uymayan bir başkan adayını öldürüp suçu bir polis kıza atıyor. Bu kızda bizim kardeşimiz. Bizim amacımız ise olayı çözüp kardeşimizi suçsuz hale getirmek. Yani tatlı bir hikayeye sahip. Chapter'ların arasında giren çizim tarzında ara sahnelere de sahip. Ara sahneler güzel ama nedense karakterimiz aşırı çirkin yani bu tarzının nedenini anlıyorum ama aynı tarzda daha güzel bir ana karakter olabilirdi, neyse. Oyunun dünyası çok stabil. Sadece 3 renk var ve her yerde aynı şeyler karşına çıkıp duruyor. Baya ruhsuz bir dünyaya sahip. Bu bir tasarım tercihi onu anlıyorum ve oyun kısa olduğundan aşırı bir problem değil ama genede daha iyi olabilirdi. Bunun dışında oyundaki aksiyon oldukça kötü. Sadece kaçmıyoruz oyun bazen bizi savaşmaya da zorluyor. Genel tarz yumruklarla dövüşüp adamda olan kısa bir anı yakalayıp orada counter atmak ve silahını almak üzerine. O silahı kullanıp minik aksiyonlara girebiliyoruz ama silahla aksiyon yumrukla aksiyondan çok kat daha kötü. Seslendirmeler güzel. Finalin epikliği oldukça az ama hikayeyi güzelce bitiriyor. 

Kısacası parkur oyunlarının oldukça güzel örneklerinden biri hızlı tempodaki oyunları , sinematik oyunları ya da parkur oyunlarını seviyorsanız , kaçırmayın. Ben öneriyorum. 🥈🅖🅤🅜🅤🅢🥈

185566480.review: Отличная игра про паркур. Геймплей и стиль в этой игре-самые сильные стороны. Безумно приятно без остановки паркурить, убегая от копов и создавая flow. Единственный минус пожалуй это линейность, все уровни проходят по одному маршруту и поэтому шикарный паркур не раскрывается в полной мере. Нарисованные кат сцены сделаны шикарно, все было интересно смотреть. Из доп контента тут это только собирательство сумок. Сюжет-средний, персонажи хоть и харизматичные, но из-за короткого повествования не успевают раскрыться. В целом очень рекомендую эту игру! Pero se que forjaré mi propio camino y destino sin que nada ni nadie me detenga...'' así empieza Mirror's Edge la joyita infravalorada de Electronic Arts (cuando hacían juegazos) y que a mi parecer esta mucho mas pulido que el Catalyst sobretodo en sus diseños pero lejos de eso no sabría como describir este juego ni tampoco que decir que no hayan dicho ya pero hay algo que si que quiero decir y es que este juego transmite a la perfección hacia donde se dirige el mundo es un juegazo clásico adelantado a su época salio por allá por el 2009 es decir que han pasado mas de 15 años desde su lanzamiento y poco se ha hablado de el y es una lastima porque ofrece bastante aunque parezca que no Mirror's Edge nos transporta a un futuro aparentemente utópico pero claramente distópico donde una ciudad de miles de puntos como paradigma geográfico universal una especie de Neo Tokyo cual ciudad de Akira una ciudad donde los datos compartidos están optimizados... las personas, las calles, los coches, los puentes, las motos, y los runners que recorren la ciudad como palomas aguilas y cuervos... 185169425.review:
Ponderei muito antes de escrever esta review. Desde o lançamento, fiquei encantado pelo estilo artístico do jogo, mas, infelizmente, meu computador da época não conseguia rodá-lo — especialmente porque o PhysX era uma novidade que exigia bastante hardware. Alguns anos depois, finalmente tive a chance de jogar, e vou dizer: não me decepcionei nem um pouco.
Na época, o jogo me cativou pelo estilo inovador de gameplay, algo completamente novo para mim. A arte é simplesmente maravilhosa; é possível perceber o cuidado dos artistas em cada detalhe, desde as cover arts até os pequenos conceitos de personagens e a atmosfera envolvente.
As cutscenes são uma verdadeira cereja do bolo. Adoro o estilo único que usaram nelas. Embora algumas pessoas reclamem, considero essas cenas um marco que define muito bem a identidade de Mirror’s Edge.

Pontos Negativos
Apesar de ter um lugar especial no meu coração, é importante abordar os pontos negativos, porque nenhum jogo é perfeito, e Mirror’s Edge também tem suas falhas.
O jogo é de 2009, e ao rejogá-lo hoje, é perceptível como o tempo passou. Os gráficos deixam evidente sua idade, e alguns elementos — como o combate — ficaram um pouco datados.
Outro problema é o stutter de carregamento em algumas cenas. Esses travamentos, embora breves e localizados em momentos específicos, acabaram quebrando a imersão em certos trechos.

Conclusão
Ainda assim, eu super recomendo Mirror’s Edge, especialmente porque ele não exige nenhum launcher da EA e costuma estar bem barato em promoções. Este jogo marcou minha trajetória como pessoa, e espero que, se decidir dar uma chance a ele, você se divirta tanto quanto eu.

185059010.review:
[h2]Positive aspects[/h2]

This game has it's own identity, very appealing art style and visual design in general. The cutscenes were a pleasant surprise for me. It took me back in time when you would play a game as a kid and you get that feeling like something special but subtle is going on. It's really unique in a way, and that's the feeling that made me push through the game. I'm a sucker for nostalgia. Gameplay itself is versatile, it leaves you space for planning a route through the sections and that adds a lot, because you get the badass feeling. Sometimes you can go full James Bond and sometimes you can just skedaddle.

[h2]Negative aspects[/h2]

Thank god there's no achievements on steam for this game. Man, even though I do recommend playing this game considering how old it is, it's a pain in the ass nonetheless. The parkour is great but the movement is outdated. I hated the [spoiler]scaffolding[/spoiler] section of the game cuz that's the part the parkour really underperformed for me. The story is nothing extraordinary, but it's enjoyable. Some checkpoint runs are tedious, not even joking. I remember repeating one long-ass section over and over again and dying to some of the most ridiculous shi for like 10 times, to the point that it makes you turn it off and play it later.

But all in all, this game is worth giving a shot. It feels old, but looks new. Got it on discount, cuz EA...

Después de años sin jugarlo, volverlo a agarrar me generó sentimientos encontrados. Mecánicamente sigue siendo muy bueno, aunque solo en la parte de desplazamiento, porque los combates están muy toscos y poco intuitivos. Y ojo, entiendo que los disparos no sean su fuerte ya que el personaje tampoco va de esa onda, pero creo que podrían haberlo pulido un poco más.

Visualmente es excelente, minimalista pero bien aplicado, lo mismo la música. La parte artística no tiene mucho que criticarle, de hecho no se me ocurre nada puntual, todo funciona perfecto. Destaco el mapeado y los entornos, generan una buena dinámica a la hora de correr y una buena ambientación. Algunas veces no te queda muy claro para dónde ir, pero en general está bien hecho.

Ahora yendo para el lado de la historia... bueno, es una excusa para tenerte corriendo de un lado para el otro. No tiene mucha profundidad, no indaga en personajes secundarios, ni siquiera desarrola a Faith más allá de conocer un poco de su pasado y el de su hermana Kate. Pasa todo a los pedos, terminando con un "Ganamos!" y todo lo que estaba pasando al rededor deja de existir de forma completamente anticlimática y *final*. Como digo, es solo una excusa, pero funciona, tampoco es que se pretenda mucho más.

Para cerrar, buen fichín, no dura mucho y es muy divertido. Los trials son una paja mal, pero dentro de todo garpan como desafío... si te gustan esa clase de desafíos contrarreloj. En fin, recomendado

saludos!

184388166.review:
I can see why people like this game, but I've played more than one of these and ME is simply too clunky for me.

It's an absolutely gorgeous game, has great music, good story. Have no idea why they chose to render the cutscenes in that animated format, when they proved they can 3D-animate them through the rest of the game. Feels like a wasted opportunity to really show off the lighting engine and artstyle. Really reminds me of the 2000s amateur animations like Mobi the Robot. Probably made on the same software. In any case the absolutely do not hold up, especially on higher and more modern resolutions.

When the game is running on all cylinders (pun intended), its pretty good. Really liked the chase scenes or the ability to avoid the enemies with clever platforming. But the game once or twice forces you into combat and it is a slog. Not fun, hard to predict enemy movements, hard to position them out of the way of other enemies, issues with collision, and 'runner time' activation is inconsistent enough to warrant not using it, especially since it isn't toggleable. Had to turn it down to easy after the first major forced combat section. Part of the difficulty is probably because I refused to shoot people and only relied on melee combat, but actually using the guns felt like the easy way out when you're supposed to be superhuman in the way of movement. Plus, the game didn't even instruct me on how to aim the weapons down sights. I had to figure it out on the spot when they required me to use the sniper.

The above qualms sort of transition to the rest of the game. There's not enough feedback to know if what you're doing is the 'correct' way of doing things. Yes, player expression is important, but this game is a puzzle, and the developer only creates the illusion of choice. There's something like 5 different mantling/climbing animations. I have no idea if they are tied to height and speed of drop when clambering, or if they are just random. But sometimes performing the same jump would lead to an incredibly slow climb-up animation in the middle of combat. Not great. Sometimes you will land on an enemy and OHKO them. Sometimes you will bounce off their head like a rubber ball. Some interactables you can wallrun into, some you have to jump to. Sometimes you can use a wallrun to get up to something, and sometimes it requires a reverse-walljump. While both visually look feasible, the game wants you to do a specific move, and may auto-fail you if you aren't doing the exact right thing. Lastly, the level design is linear, but because of the parkour portion its hard to see where I need to go. Sometimes the game will let you use the 'look to objective' button, but sometimes it doesn't work, and honestly it would have been nice to have a better indicator of where I should be going if the game isn't going to be intuitive about it. Dead Space had a similar mentality about integrating the HUD into the game (also published by EA), but there's only so many places to go in a tight corridored spaceship. ME is made to be a very open game, there have been plenty of times where I say 'hey, I want to go there', and its not an accessible or important space. Or I straight up have no idea where to go because the exit point is entirely too hidden. The game should beckon me towards where it wants me to go with its design, and then present the challenge at the execution stage.

Anyways, its a cool concept. I didn't *not* enjoy playing it. But it wasn't as much of a standout as I was hoping. Honestly I enjoyed Ghostrunner and even Titanfall 2's movement more than this games, and I didn't even finish Ghostrunner because it was too difficult.

184357634.review:
Mirror's Edge: A Masterpiece in Motion

Rating: 9/10

Mirror's Edge is nothing short of a masterpiece. From the moment you step into the shoes of Faith, a fearless runner in a vibrant, futuristic city, you're immediately swept into a world that feels both exhilarating and dangerous. The game's fluid, parkour-inspired movement mechanics are a breath of fresh air, offering a level of freedom and immersion rarely seen in platforming games. Navigating the sleek, white rooftops while chaining together smooth, acrobatic moves is a joy, and the game's emphasis on speed, precision, and fluidity makes every moment of movement feel like an accomplishment.

The world-building in Mirror's Edge is equally remarkable. The minimalist aesthetic of the city, with its pristine white buildings and splashes of bold primary colors, creates a visual identity that's both futuristic and unsettling. It’s a perfect backdrop for the high-paced, tense environment that Faith and her fellow runners inhabit. The contrast between the stark cityscape and the human emotion felt within the story is striking, adding depth to an otherwise simple narrative. The art direction here is nothing short of genius, and the setting plays a key role in making the game world come to life.

The soundtrack is also an integral part of what makes Mirror's Edge so special. From the soaring beats of the main theme to the heart-pounding electro rhythms during chase sequences, the music complements the game’s pacing and immersion perfectly. It doesn’t just sit in the background; it drives the action, amplifies the tension, and reinforces the emotional moments within the narrative. It's a soundtrack that sticks with you long after you've finished the game.

However, while the game is a shining example of innovation in its movement and world-building, there is one significant misstep— the shooting mechanics towards the end. As Mirror's Edge progresses, the game asks you to engage in combat, something that feels a bit out of place considering how much the gameplay prioritizes movement and acrobatics. The shooting feels clunky and disrupts the fluidity that the parkour mechanics build up to. It's not that the combat is terrible, but it pales in comparison to the core gameplay, and its inclusion detracts from the otherwise perfect rhythm of the game. By the time you’re battling your way through enemies, you can’t help but wish the game had stuck to its strengths rather than forcing an element that doesn’t quite fit.

In conclusion, Mirror's Edge is a rare gem— a game that pushes boundaries with its movement system, immersive world-building, and fantastic soundtrack. While the shooting mechanics at the end detract from the overall experience, they don’t tarnish what is otherwise a breathtaking and unforgettable adventure. If you haven’t played it yet, don’t let the ending deter you; the journey is more than worth it.

Graphics look really nice even though they are old and have a good feel to it. However the lighting in some parts wasn't great (may be due to my monitor but you can change the settings so it looks fine if it is especially bad in one area. You don't need much to run this so don't worry if your pc/laptop isn't great.

Gameplay is REALLY FUN. Honestly, you could sit there for hours and play. The movement is really fun and also can be challenging at times making you think on what to do. The game does time really well as it gives a realistic time for enemies to appear whilst still letting you have a chance to process and figure something out. However, there are parts where disarming a guard may be hard as the red portion doesn't show up for long but there are many ways to get round this such as punching, slowing time, etc. Also there is basically no grinding unless you want to do time trials but the main story doesn't require grinding at all.

The audio is really nice and I was amazed at the voice acting and sound effects. When I first fell down from a high place, there was a splattering sound that I thought sounded really good and also gory (nothing was shown). Personally, I didn't like the music that much so I put on spotify and turned it down for dialogue which I found much more fun like the character was wearing headphones or something like that. 

Also, this game is aimed for younger teens to adults as story may be complicated and mentions of blood, murder with use of guns throughout. Though it is up to the parent to decide ultimately.

I won't spoil anything for the story and don't look up anything about it as the story has plot twists which I loved. Overall, the story is AMAZING.

No bugs that I found btw

Overall, I think for me this game was a 10/10 because of how the whole game immerses you with it's story, realism (in some aspects), graphics, but overall it's fun. I really recommend you at least buy this and try it for 2 hours. If you don't like it you can refund it.

184145369.review:
A beautiful game made with something so rarely seen nowadays - passion and vision. For that alone I would recommend it despite all its flaws, as the game has such a unique atmosphere and is always a comforting one to return to.

The art direction cannot be understated, the game looks amazing even today thanks to its full colour palette and careful choices when it comes to designing the world. You quickly learn what each colour means, what it represents, and most importantly - what it's connected to. You can name any level from Mirror's Edge and a colour immediately comes to mind, be it the white of the everpresent skyscrapers all around you, green of the sewage system or yellow/orange of the maintenance areas. And of course, red, the one that stands out the most, the Runners' colour - your colour. And who could ever talk about this game without mentioning its gorgeous theme "Still Alive" and the adrenaline-filled or calm, serene soundtrack, depending on if you're in a chase with the police, or just cruising above the streets.

The greatest problem of this game is knowledge. Knowledge, as in, how different your first and second and third playthrough are going to look like. Your knowledge of the mechanics, levels and especially the combat system. The game's famous freerunning flow cannot shine if you don't know the way, the correct turn to take, if you just stumble around searching for some kind of clue as to where to go; and the game falls apart, there is no flow state anymore, just awkwardness. The parkour system is unreliable at first (some camera-determined actions...) and you're going to fail and be rightfully angry at the game for being so confusing. However, after a while, you'll learn what's usually possible and what's not. This is not a game based on unlockable perks or equipment, but solely on each player's skill. So, if you play it for the first time and it doesn't match your expectations, give it a second chance. Learn the combat system from tutorials or on your own, it is never really properly explained unfortunately. It still can suck if you're fighting too many enemies at once, but the fistfight boss is really fun after you learn what each attack does and how to dodge efficiently.

And once you get the hang of everything, there will be no game quite like Mirror's Edge for you - every element of this masterpiece comes together to create one of the most mesmerizing experiences gaming can offer. My one and only gripe with the game is how it forces you to engage in weapons combat in a few sections, particularly during the boat level. I want to throw the weapon away as fast as possible and get back to running, back to the true Mirror's Edge, the one with the flow and elegance. 

And yeah, it's quite short, you can clearly see how the development was rushed, especially with the final "bossfight", however, because of the points mentioned earlier, it is a very replayable game.

183999226.review:
Mirror’s Edge is the parkour-loving, first-person adrenaline rush you never knew you needed. Imagine you’re living in a sleek, futuristic city where everyone is staring at their phones, and the government is basically Big Brother with a serious need for control. Enter Faith Connors, the badass parkour runner who’s out to throw a wrench in the system and deliver some seriously stylish deliveries. And by deliveries, I mean epic rooftop jumps, gravity-defying sprints, and insane flips over fences—all while being chased by riot police, helicopters, and whatever else this dystopian world can throw at you. If you ever wanted to feel like you were part of an action movie, Mirror’s Edge is your ticket. And the best part? You’re not just running—you’re flowing through the environment, using every ledge, wall, and corner to your advantage like you’ve mastered the art of free-running in your sleep.

What makes Mirror’s Edge special? It’s the fluidity. The game has this smooth, almost rhythmic feeling to it that you just can’t get anywhere else. Every jump feels like you’re gliding through the air, every vault over an obstacle is satisfying, and every slide under a low barrier makes you feel like an Olympic-level athlete. It’s not just running from point A to point B; it’s about the journey—the way you move through the world. The game’s mechanics give you a sense of speed and grace, and even though you’re constantly being chased by enemies, you can’t help but feel like a parkour artist in a high-stakes action scene. There’s nothing like sprinting across rooftops, narrowly dodging a sniper bullet, and landing perfectly on the next building without missing a beat. This is not just a game; it’s a visual symphony of free-running and cinematic chaos.

Then there’s the stunning world design. The city of Mirror’s Edge is a bright, minimalist dystopia where the contrast of the pristine white buildings and sharp red accents make every jump and flip feel even more dramatic. The environments are like an interactive art piece—every rooftop, every hallway, every alleyway feels designed for maximum fluidity. The game’s lack of HUD (heads-up display) puts the emphasis entirely on the player’s movement, making you feel even more immersed in Faith’s world. It’s a beautifully designed city that almost becomes a character itself. Plus, the game’s atmospheric soundtrack—chill yet intense—only adds to the whole experience. If you love games that make you feel like you’re part of a fluid, fast-paced world and enjoy challenging yourself with precision platforming, Mirror’s Edge is a must-play. It’s a rare gem in the world of first-person action games, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone who loves heart-pumping action and sleek, parkour-filled adventures. You’ll never look at a building the same way again!

183997616.review:
Unfortunately I haven't experienced this at the time of its release. I'm sure that this would've rocked my socks off tremendously back then.

I finally managed to play and finish it. It is aesthetically beautiful and the idea of a parcours gameplay is still pretty revolutionary. I was stunned by the visuals, sounds and environment. The premise of the game was pretty interesting. However, the course of the story gets underwhelming by the minute. The ending was pretty lame.

The free-running felt terribly challenging at times, there was no clear direction of where to go. Despite trying to interact with walls and fences on a timely manner, half of them didn't register properly, which lead me to dying so often, breaking 80% of my momentum, and ruined my fun. The controls felt very wonky when trying to fight the cops. It frustrated me a lot when I couldn't disarm them, the timing was there when their weapons glowed red, yet it didn't register. It took me around 50 tries to just finish a chapter because of the horrible control input.

Making this game focusing mostly on doing parcours, but expects you to fight the cops too with your bare hands every time is a terrible game design choice. 

If you would like to know, is this game worth it? Visually, yes, and for its music the game is worthy of that too. You won't miss out much on the story, it is underwhelming as I said before. The game is also very short.

But for controls and mechanics, you'll find better free-running successors like the Assassin's Creed series or Dying Light. Because they fleshed out the parcours element well!

183916880.review:
First Time Gameplay: https://youtu.be/JOT4YfLEWWc

I played the Ghostrunner Demo way before I got to try this game and I have always wondered; "who the hell is this tough game for?". After playing Mirror's Edge I realized the inspiration and why it exists. Mirror's Edge makes it fun to run on rooftops and jump across buildings, the first person makes it more engaging and personal how you're able to see the city through the character's eyes and understand the risks they're taking with their lives with each leap. The visual aspects of the game is aesthetically pleasing the way they contrast white with red everywhere, it doesn't only help direct you on where to go but makes the city look futuristic and beautiful too. The character design is one of the best things about this game, luckily it came out way before people whined about things being "too woke" whenever a woman is included, especially one of a different race. The story is not complex, deep or though-provoking, but it is pretty engaging in getting to follow it through to the end. I would have prefered the sequel continues with this story and expands on it instead of trying a soft reboot. The visual aspects of incorporating 2D style animation for the cut scenes is also something that I enjoy about this game. It is a story about a parkour gang that find themselves against the law and the rabbit hole only gets deeper from there. I can see how it can inspire beyond parkour culture by including fashion and architecture as well, that is how beautiful this game is. Also, I know it is because they want to discourage from weapon use as Faith isn't a killer, but the shooting is bad, like bad bad!.

183619806.review:
After watching The Gaming Brit Show's excellent review of the game, I decided to finally take the plunge and try it out for myself, especially since it was on sale.

Firstly, I just want to say that I love the overall aesthetic of the game. The color palette, the music, and the vibe of the levels are fantastic. I really wish there were more games similar to this. As The Gaming Brit Show pointed out, this game embraces the fruitiger aero aesthetic—a unique style rarely seen in futuristic dystopian settings.

Now, onto the gameplay: it is absolutely top-notch, with almost no filler or downtime. It delivers pure, engaging fun and feels like an excellent evolution of the 3D platformer genre. I just wish this game were more popular, as it could have inspired similar titles to follow in its footsteps.

The only real downsides are the story and cutscenes, which could have been better—but who knows? Overall, I highly recommend the game. It genuinely surprises me that EA published this gem.
